awd_titl_txt: Role of Low-Level Clouds in the Accelerated Warming of the Great Lakes - A Dual Observational and Regional Modeling Assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a study of the warming trends in surface temperatures of the Great Lakes since the mid-1980s.  Great Lakes surface temperature trends have been upward during this period in all seasons, especially in summer, and the summer surface temperatures in lakes Huron and Michigan have increased by 4 degrees Celsius.  This rate of warming, in excess of 1.3C per decade, is greater by a factor of 10 than regional surface air temperature trends over the same period. The warming of the lakes has a number of consequences, including a reduction in lake level due to evaporation, which historically has been a second-order effect compared to rainfall variations but has recently become comparable in magnitude due to the higher temperatures.  The prevailing hypothesis for the rapid warming is that reduced winter ice cover leads to earlier springtime stratification and an increase in the number of heating days through the summer, thereby accounting for the large trend in warm season temperature.  But the impact reduced ice cover may not be sufficient to account for the observed warming without additional amplifying mechanisms.  Research conducted in this project tests the hypothesis that the temperature increase is amplified by feedbacks involving fog and low cloud cover, in which warmer lake temperatures lead to reductions in fog and low cloud, which in turn expose lake surfaces to increased insolation. The impact of changes in fog and low cloud, as well as other warming mechanisms, will be examined using a suite of numerical modeling simulations.  Expected outcomes of the research are 1) the identification of various factors that are driving the observed water-surface temperature increases in all of the Great Lakes; 2) estimation of future water-surface temperature increases; 3) assessment of current and future lake-level decreases which will result from increased evaporation; 4) identification of regional climate impacts stemming from global warming induced changes in the Great Lakes' behavior.

The work will have broader impacts beyond the scientific questions addressed.  Warming lake temperatures have a number of undersirable consequences for the Great Lakes ecosystem and fisheries, including excessive primary production, algal blooms, and consequent hypoxia as excess organic matter decomposes.  These effects are associated with "dead zones" and fish kills. The Principal Investigators are active members of the Wisconsin Initiative on Climate Change Impacts (WICCI) and pledge to share their findings with relevant working groups of WICCI including the Coastal Communities, Water Resources, and Coldwater Fish Working Groups.  In addition, the project supports and trains two graduate students and a postdoc, thereby providing for the next generation of researchers in this area.

por.por_cntn:
The Laurentian Great Lakes experienced accelerated summertime warming, compared to local terrestrial air and most lakes worldwide. The primary drivers of this accelerated warming from 1982 to 2012 were explored through observations, remote sensing, and numerical experiments using a hierarchy of regional climate models. Our most sophisticated model had a state-of-the-art atmospheric component represented by the International Centre for Theoretical Physics (ICTP) Regional Climate Model Version Four (RegCM4), interactively coupled to a one-dimensional thermodynamic lake/ice component (hereafter, coupled RegCM4 model). A much more idealized model we used (hereafter, the EBM coupled model) had a similar thermodynamic lake/ice component, albeit with a much coarser horizontal resolution of a few columns per lake, but, most importantly, replaced the RegCM4 model with an energy-balance atmospheric formulation.

The greatest lake warming between 1997 and 1998 occurred over the deepest areas of Lake Superior during mid-summer. RegCM4 results suggest that this warming primarily resulted from enhanced heat accumulation during the mild winter of 1997/1998 and was amplified by greater incoming surface solar radiation and air temperature during spring 1998. The mild winter condition, together with the increased solar radiation and air temperature during spring, caused an earlier onset of springtime stratification, resulting in enhanced heat absorption by surface water and thereby contributing to lake surface warming during the subsequent summer in 1998 compared with 1997. By contrast, the modest peak warming over southern lakes and shallow areas of northern lakes from 1997 to 1998 was a rapid response to synchronous increases in solar radiation and air temperature during May between the two years. Within the coupled RegCM4 model, changes in antecedent wintertime lake ice cover, and, hence, the lake-ice–albedo feedback, were found to have played only a minor role in the accelerated warming trend of the Laurentian Great Lakes.

The RegCM4 simulations were, however, found to underestimate the observed 1997/98 warming of Lake Superior by about 30% and the long-term, 1982–2012 warming trend by about 60%, mostly due to simulating warmer-than-observed lake conditions in 1982–1997. On the other hand, the EBM coupled model’s version configured to represent Lake Superior captured both the 1997/98 transition to a warm climate regime, as well as the observed decadal persistence of the pre-1998 cold state. We demonstrated that nonlinearity associated with the ice–albedo feedback, which leads to the existence, in the EBM coupled model, of multiple stable seasonal cycles under identical seasonally varying forcing (nonlinear climate regimes), is central in explaining the observed characteristics of the recent Great Lakes’ warming. Notably, the same EBM model, but with the ice–albedo feedback artificially suppressed by setting the ice albedo to that of open water, is only able to capture about 60% of the observed warming, thus underestimating the long-tern decadal warming in ways similar to the coupled RegCM4 model. We thus conjecture that the differences between the RegCM4 coupled model and the coupled EBM model stem primarily from the apparent lack of regime dynamics in the former, most probably due to the differences in their ice model formulations and the lake model’s convective mixing schemes, and thus the resulting lack of interannual persistence in the RegCM4 simulated cold state of the lake.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in significantly furthering our understanding of the dynamics of Great Lakes’ accelerated climate change. In particular, we developed a novel nonlinear dynamical framework to interpret the Great Lakes regional climate change in the background of the larger-scale warming. Furthermore, in conjunction with other funded projects, we developed future climatic and limnological projections for the Great Lakes Basin by dynamically downscaling output from a subset of six global climate models using the coupled RegCM4 model. These projections have been applied to a wide range of scientific explorations. As for further broader impacts, this project addressed a fundamental problem in regional manifestations of global climate change; the insights gained via this research are likely to be relevant for understanding a similar ubiquitous phenomenon observed worldwide in other large lakes. Furthermore, this project has already sparked interest in related fields of hydrology (since accelerated lake warming results in an enhanced evaporation and overall freshwater budget of the region) and lake biology (since biological effects/feedbacks are thought to possibly contribute to the observed lake warming). Finally, understanding of physics and predictability of the accelerated Great Lakes warming is bound to have an impact on the policy and social planning of the Great Lakes communities (climate-change adaptation, Great Lakes water-level variability and related dredging project effects etc.) This is reflected in a large number of interviews and invited public talks given by the research-team members throughout the project. The results from this research were presented in 7 invited talks or keynote addresses and 22 conference presentations, and produced 6 major peer-reviewed papers, one book chapter and one PhD dissertation.
